item.title: Battlefield 6: What is Pax Armata?
item.description:
The pre-release hype surrounding Battlefield 6 is now in full swing, with DICE finally gearing up to launch the project's Open Beta over the coming weeks. This has been compounded by the first official trailers for the upcoming game, which are currently mainly focused on the title's ambitious single-player narrative. While the Battlefield franchise has produced some stellar campaigns over the years, there is a lot of pressure for BF6 's story to make a real statement compared to what fans have seen with recent releases.

The official trailers and teasers for Battlefield 6 and its story mode largely corroborate a lot of the earliest leaks and theories surrounding the project. For example, it was often cited that the game's story would be centered around a large-scale conflict between NATO and a faction known as Pax Armata. Now confirmed, a lot of mystery still surrounds the formation and purpose of Pax Armata, but some solid theories can already be crafted based on what DICE has already revealed.

Battlefield 6's Pax Armata is a Force To Be Reckoned With

DICE has been very upfront about the inspiration that past games like Battlefield 3 and Battlefield 4 have had for the development of BF6 , with this being echoed in the upcoming title's approach to its single-player experience. Like BF3 and BF4 , Battlefield 6 's campaign will feature the same massive stakes, high-octane set-pieces, and a modern to near-future setting. It seems as if Battlefield 6 's featured fictional conflict will be one of the largest that the franchise has seen, with a spate of large-scale attacks occurring all over the world.

Recent Battlefield games have opted for episodic War Stories for single-player experiences, with Battlefield 2042 opting to do away with a campaign completely. With this in mind, it is clear to see why so much excitement exists around Battlefield 6 's ambitious single-player plans.

These attacks are specifically against NATO countries and NATO infrastructure, with a nefarious group known as Pax Armata acting as the game's main antagonistic force. From Battlefield 6 's trailers, it seems as if Pax Armata has carried out near-simultaneous attacks against key targets in Gibraltar, Georgia, and Belgium, with the most recent trailer even showing New York under siege by invading forces.

Battlefield 6 's full campaign trailer sees the President of the United States refer to Pax Armata as mercenaries, but it seems as if the faction could be a full coalition of countries akin to NATO itself. The initial teaser cinematic for Battlefield 6 's campaign makes brief mention of France defecting from NATO to join the Pax Armata coalition, showcasing the severity of the faction's impact on global power dynamics.

Pax Armata's Mercenary Roots Have Grown Into Something Much More in Battlefield 6

The standard of military equipment and sheer size of Pax Armata is also worth mentioning, with the group's attacks across the globe requiring an immense amount of training, power, and financing. The name "Pax Armata" can be translated from Latin to either mean armed peace or peace through force, perhaps giving some insight into the end goals of the faction's mysterious motives. Given the antagonist history of Battlefield , it seems likely that countries like China and Russia could be at the heart of what is making Pax Armata tick.

Ultimately, Pax Armata is already shaping up to be one of the most interesting enemy factions that the Battlefield franchise has seen in quite some time. While the entity may have started as a mercenary group, it has clearly expanded rapidly and with force, being able to go toe-to-toe with the largest military coalition on the planet. While the end goals of Pax Armata remain unclear, their approach to breaking NATO is a big giveaway in terms of how they might want to reshape the Western world, leading to some fascinating potential story avenues.

item.title: How to Get All Bananas in The Junction in Donkey Kong Bananza
item.description:
The Junction , SL700, in Donkey Kong Bananza is not your traditional layer, as it's not that big, and it doesn't have any Sublayers to explore, but there are still 15 Banandium Gems to find and get to fill DK's rumbling tummy. Forget about getting to the Core --here's where to find all the bananas in SL700, The Junction , in Donkey Kong Bananza .

It's worth noting that we cleaned up all the Banandium Gems in this layer after we completed the story and rolled credits. If there are any bananas on this list that are seemingly impossible for you to obtain, try finishing the game and coming back later.

All Bananas in The Junction (SL700) in Donkey Kong Bananza

Banana #1 - Freezer Path's Special Scoop

Go to the top of the cold section of the Junction, and you'll find a Banandium Gem behind a snow sculpture.

Banana #2 - Cooled Off Inflammonite

Once you beat Inflammonite in the Freezer Layer, you'll return to The Junction and some Banandium Gems will be waiting for DK to gobble up.

Banana #3 - Freezer Path's Hidden Snack

If you go on the frozen side of The Junction, take the lower path, and you'll see a breakable wall to your left that can be destroyed by the machines aiming DK down. Trick the laser beams to shoot the wall to reveal a hidden Banana.

Banana #4 - Shifty Smash: Freezer Path

Head towards the icy section of the layer and take the lower path to find a mud path with lasers pointed at you. Go to the end of the path to find one of those mystery pyramid things . Smack it and complete the challenge to earn yourself a Banandium Gem. You'll have 20 seconds to destroy the cubes that appear.

Banana #5 - Forest Path's Birdbrain

Near the Forest Bridge checkpoint, head up to the top of the cliff to find a snake statue. You can break its head apart to find a hidden Banandium Gem.

Banana #6 - Uprooted Abracajabya

After you leave the Forest Layer and beat Abracajabya, you'll get yourself three Banandium Gems as soon as you land in The Junction.

Banana #7 - Forest Path's Hidden Snack

From the Clash Point checkpoint, go towards the Forest area, but stay on the lower path leading to the missiles. You can lead them to the rock wall to destroy it, revealing a banana, but it's behind a gate.

You can reach it by climbing the wall to the left and shimmying your way around to the Gem.

Banana #8 - Shifty Smash: Forest Path

Head to the forest path, but stay on the lower end, and go past the missiles and thorns to find one of the pyramid objects you can hit to start a challenge. Destroy the cubes within 20 seconds to earn another Banandium Gem. Make sure to use the lasers to your advantage!

Remember that you can slap the ground with the R button to get a look at nearby collectibles. You can also upgrade your Sonar power in the Skills tree by unlocking more Banandium Gems. Be on the lookout for treasure chests, too, as they can contain maps leading DK to Fossils and new Bananas.

Banana #9 - Cleared the Way to Clash Point

You'll find a Banandium Gem out in the open once you reach the Clash Point checkpoint.

Banana #10 - Clash Point's Hidden Snack

If you're standing at the Clash Point fast travel checkpoint, drop off the edge near the two talking Fractones. You'll see a cube sticking out that you can stand on, which leads to a hidden cave with a smashable wall and a Banandium Gem.

Banana #11 - Battle: A Fiery Fracas

You can find the Junction Battle Challenge 1 near the Warp Gong. If you are facing the gong from the open, walk over to the right side of the structure before you to find a challenge room blocked by rocks. You can pay the Constructone 600 Gold to unblock it.

Banana #12, 13, and 14

You will find a blocked-off challenge room near the Warp Gong. Pay the nearby Constructone 1000 Gold to access it. There will be three Banandium Gems to collect in the Crossing Through Crosshairs challenge course.

Banana #15 - Cranky's Junction Rant

In the main area with the Warp Gong, you can see Cranky Kong and Rambi on platforms way up in the air. If you stand on the platform next to the Clash Point checkpoint, you should be able to bring them down by tossing rocks.

item.title: Donkey Kong Bananza Has a Learning Curve That Future Nintendo Games Shouldn't Shy Away From
item.description:
Nintendo isn't really known for making difficult games. Given that the vast majority of Nintendo's first-party output is designed to target younger gamers, the company's biggest games usually have a very low barrier to entry in terms of difficulty. Enemies can often be taken down in just one or two hits, the controls are usually streamlined, and the general gameplay loop remains straightforward throughout. But Donkey Kong Bananza subverts this tradition ever so slightly.

Donkey Kong Bananza is far from a difficult game. Enemy health is low, the cost of player-death is minimal, and the majority of boss fights are absurdly easy. That said, Donkey Kong Bananza features a surprisingly steep learning curve within its first hour or so, and while that might put some players off, it should only reaffirm Nintendo's future plans.

Future Nintendo Games Should Embrace Donkey Kong Bananza's Learning Curve

Donkey Kong Bananza Throws a Lot at New Players

The first hour of Donkey Kong Bananza can be a surprisingly overwhelming one for some players. To begin with, Donkey Kong Bananza presents players with a fairly novel control scheme, where the face buttons on the right Joy-Con correspond to a unique directional attack. These directional inputs aren't quite as intuitive as they should be, and matters aren't helped by the jump button being assigned to the 'A' button as opposed to 'B'.

While players are still wrapping their heads around this slightly quirky control scheme, Donkey Kong Bananza piles a mountain of interweaving mechanics and gameplay systems on top of them. Within half an hour, players are taught about Donkey Kong Bananza 's destruction mechanics, the game's multiple currencies, the various types of collectibles hidden in its levels, the ability to use terrain as a weapon and traversal method, and its unexpectedly extensive skill tree.

And while players are trying to get to grips with the game's control scheme and everything they've learned, they're presented with Donkey Kong Bananza 's open-ended level design, where players are thrown into a large area and tasked with exploring it however they see fit using all of the game's overlapping mechanics and systems. It's a lot for new players to take on board and put into practice right away. But with just a little patience, Donkey Kong Bananza 's complexity soon becomes its best strength.

Donkey Kong Bananza's Complexity Is The Key to its Success

After an hour or two, Donkey Kong Bananza 's gameplay loop starts to make a lot more sense, its control scheme becomes much more intuitive, and its mechanical complexity becomes a highlight of the experience, with the game's great level of player-freedom paving the way for engaging experimentation when it comes to traversal methods and completing the game's various puzzles and bonus stages.

As players progress through Donkey Kong Bananza 's main story, they'll continue to unlock new abilities that add fascinating new layers to the already-dense gameplay loop. It's this continually evolving depth that keeps players hooked throughout Donkey Kong Bananza 's 20-hour runtime and beyond, and it should convince Nintendo that it doesn't need to shy away from delivering more mechanically-complex games like this in the near future.

item.title: Supervive: Best Changes Since The Beta
item.description:
Supervive , the MOBA Battle Royale game, has finally left its open beta, and the 1.0 release comes with a vast array of sweeping changes. Almost every aspect of the game has been changed in one way or another, meaning players have lots to check out and learn.

At its core, Supervive remains incredibly fun to play, with an ever-expanding roster of Hunters with plenty of outplay potential and satisfying combos. This article will only cover the biggest and best changes to Supervive , but expect to find many more in the Breach.

7 Trios Instead Of Duos & Teams Of Four

Shorter Queue Times & More Individual Agency

One of the most simple yet impactful changes to Supervive since the game initially launched is that the team size has been altered. Initially, players had two options: duos or squads of four, but these queues have now been combined into one, with teams now being comprised of three Hunters.

This should speed up queue time, and as squads were the main way of playing the game, players should now have more individual agency, as they now account for a third of their team rather than a quarter. Team fights should also have more clarity, with only six combatants rather than eight. The only downside is that this sucks for groups of four friends, but they can always play the Arena mode.

6 New Hunters

There Are Now 22 Hunters In Supervive

At the start of the open beta, Supervive had sixteen hunters to choose from, but since then, six more have been released, bringing the total to twenty-two. Wukong is the most recent hunter, having been released alongside the 1.0 patch, and there will be two more released in the following month at two-week intervals.

The new hunters to look out for are Beebo, Crysta, Carbine, Saros, Eva, and Wukong, with these all covering different roles and bringing new abilities to the table. Naturally, changes have also been made to the original roster, and balancing will continue.

5 Quests Have Been Removed

Players Shouldn't Feel As Constricted In The Early Game

While many of the changes to Supervive are additions or reworks, some features have been straight-up removed. For example, in-game quests are completely gone. In the beta, teams would drop in a choose a simple quest, such as farming camps, breaking into a vault, or killing enemy hunters.

Quests do not appear to have been replaced with any other feature; instead, players should feel free to do whatever they like at the start of the game, with farming camps to level up usually being the preferred option.

4 Armor Is Now Repaired Via Consumable Shards

It Can Still Be Repaired At Forges, But Not At Base Camps

In the beta, armor could be repaired at Base Camps, which still exist, but no longer have this function. Instead, the most common way to repair armor is by obtaining Armor Shards, a consumable that is activated by pressing the 2 key. Upon being consumed, one bar of armor will be repaired.

Players will pick up Armor Shards as random loot, and upon killing enemy players, they will pick up any they were carrying. Armor can also be recharged for free at a forge, although this will make a loud noise, alerting the enemy to your presence.

3 A Larger Map With More Aerial Traversal

Prepare To Relearn Your Way Around

Supervive 's map, 'The Breach,' has been expanded, meaning games should feel more unique as the safe zone has more locations to spawn. Additionally, there is more empty space, which players will have to use their newly upgraded gliders to traverse. Alternatively, they can ride around in Skysharks, a new vehicle that seats two players and is at its fastest in the abyss.

The spawn locations of monsters and bosses have also been altered. Combined with the addition of tonnes of new shops, and all the other changes, it's safe to say players will need to relearn their way around.

2 Gliders No Longer Run Out Of Fuel

Gliding Is Also Less Risky

Gliders are one of the best things about Supervive , with them offering a fun form of traversal rarely seen in MOBA-like games. In the beta, players had to manage their glider fuel, and getting shot while gliding would result in an instant spike while hovering over the abyss.

However, gliders no longer run out of fuel, meaning players can keep going, especially with the help of new jetstreams. Additionally, being hit while gliding will not result in a spike, unless the glider has overheated. Using the glider too much and being hit will cause it to gain heat. All of this means gliding is less risky, but there is still some management to using them.

1 Old Items Are Gone, Replaced By The Armory

Items Are Now Unlocked Between Games & Bought With Gold In Game

The biggest change of all to Supervive is the addition of the Armory, which replaces all the old items and how hunters are built. From now on, items are bought with gold from various traders found throughout the map. This is instead of collecting pink item shards that gradually upgrade items.

However, the important thing is that players must first unlock these items in the Armory, which is accessed outside of games. To do so, players will need to earn Prisma, such as by killing enemies and taking half of theirs. This change aims to improve player retention time as players can look forward to unlocking new and improved items or runes, but this also means not everyone is on a level playing field in each match. Powers in Supervive are also part of the Armory now.

item.title: Destiny 2: How to Easily Get A-Rank on Ops
item.description:
Destiny 2: The Edge of Fate makes a permanent change to endgame content with the Portal, a centralized HUB to allow players to choose different activities with a plethora of optional modifiers to increase rewards. The best reward that players can get in Destiny 2 is through the A-Rank, so players will want to know what modifiers will get them to the A-Rank as quickly as possible, without making the activity too challenging, as nobody wants to add Combatant Power if they don't need to.

If you are wondering why you should go for A-Rank in Ops activities, it's because it will provide the highest boost to Power in completion Engrams.

Best Difficulty Modifiers For A-Rank in Destiny 2

What Difficulty Modifiers Make an Easy A-Rank?

The easiest way to get an A-Rank through difficulty modifiers in The Portal is by using the Equipment Locked Activity modifier in the Player Stakes tab . This modifier will add loadout restrictions, meaning players are unable to change out their loadouts throughout the entire activity . While this might mean no hotswapping to other builds for damage and different encounters, most players should have a build that they can confidently run through the activity that they have selected. Choosing the Equipment Locked Activity is perfect, as it grants a x5 Challenge Multiplier . For most difficulties, like Expert, players will not need any additional modifiers to hit A-Rank, but players in Master and Grandmaster might.

Since Master and Grandmaster is far harder than Expert due to the Combatant Power level, players will still want to use Equipment Locked Activity, but alongside other Challenge Modifiers. Players do not want to select Challenge Modifiers that will provide +20 Combatant Power, as that will simply put them in a bad time. Instead, rely on +10 Combatant Power Challenge Modifiers in the Faction Drop and Minor Negative Modifiers, as these will provide players with modifiers that might boost Combatant Power, but they will not really give enemies a tactical advantage, as all these modifiers do is drop a trap when enemies are eliminated.
